replies.msg:
As a Catalan, I would like to clarify some inaccuracies and misinformation regarding the situation in Catalonia that have been present in some posts, for the benefit of Hong Kongers and foreigners here who may not be completely aware of the differences between the Catalan separatist movement and the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong. I will try to be as brief as possible.

**1)**

Hong Kongers: five just demands comprising basic human and civil rights.

Catalan separatists: fighting against a democracy to establish a pseudo-Marxist dictatorship (please check separatist parties ideology and policies)

**2)**

Hong Kong: China refuses to negotiate, responds with violence.

Catalonia: separatists refuse to negotiate. Laws can indeed be changed, but separatists don’t enjoy enough popular support to change them so they resort to violence.

**3)**

Hong Kongers: mostly peaceful, some targeted vandalism towards Chinese interests.

Catalan separatists: not peaceful, indiscriminate violence against civilians (including an old Catalan woman for waving a Spanish flag), infrastructure and police officers; +200 officers wounded, some of them critically.

**4)**

Hong Kongers: respect medical personnel, let ambulances through.

Catalan separatists: have blocked ambulances way, preventing medical personnel from treating the wounded. Also, a female doctor and her boss have been harassed by a separatist mob because she addressed a patient in Spanish.

**5)**

Hong Kong police: does not follow international standards, abuses are widespread, live ammunition used, no ID.

Spanish/Catalan regional police: follows international standards + accountability mechanisms for any given police abuse. Show ID, disperse crowds using non-lethal & proportionate force.

**6)**

Spain: full democracy.

Catalonia: autonomous region in a democratic country. The Catalan regional government controls all of Catalonia’s internal affairs. Regular elections by universal suffrage. Catalonia’s autonomy protected in the Spanish Constitution; no interference by the Spanish government.

Hong Kong: under the boot of a singe-party dictatorship. Continuous interference and human rights abuses.

**EXTRA:** [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=\_fG0qHRowU0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fG0qHRowU0)

Catalan government TV proposing to turn Barcelona’s port into a base for Chinese nuclear submarines as a way to blackmail the EU into letting them join the bloc as an independent state. Catalan separatists don't care about Hong Kong, they just want to hijack your cause to legitimize their own. They have done it with many causes before, including contradicting ones (such as Israel vs. Palestine).

Whoever believes Catalonia and Hong Kong are the same is utterly deluded. It’s very low to play on people’s emotions and lack of knowledge on a foreign dispute to lure them into supporting a cause that overtly contradicts the freedom and pro-democracy values enshrined by Hong Kongers. Hong Kong protesters are brave righteous people fighting for a noble cause, whereas Catalan separatists are anything but that.

Last but not least, it’s astonishingly ironic to wave Hong Kong’s democratic flag next to the *estelada*, the flag of a Marxist terrorist group called *Terra Lliure* that now became the flag of Catalan separatism.

喺reddit 見到，使唔使開post講吓咩事？

雖然投票唔等於贏，但投咗係百利而無一害

假設因為唔信泛民所以白票，唔想推泛民上去，咁即係間接幫咗建制上位，從結果論上同敵人冇分別

如果因為唔信個制度所以白票，我功利啲問句，而家打仗仲同佢玩清高？區議會又好立法會都好，政府出糧，又有撥款可以R。制度問題下，你未必/冇可能贏到過半議席，但你個餅分大啲，將敵人嘅本錢變自己嘅本錢，何樂而不為？最重要係開呢條戰線又唔係高成本。所以投白票同畀資源對手冇分別，結果論都係敵人
